Thanks Ken. I look forward to reading this paper.

Incidentally, we agree that nature has to deal with a lot of noise (e.g.,
the good dying young) and that it does well (e.g., produced us) despite such
noise. That's all I meant when I said that nature handles noise well. It
continues to make evolutionary progress despite being handicapped by such
noise. 

I do think some types of evolution would speed up with less noise, but noise
might also contribute greatly to robustness (which is quite high, of course,
in natural organisms).

I also agree that this is a good research area. How do we bring EC up to the
point where it can succeed despite noise to the same degree that natural
selection does? That's a difficult but important question.

Kind regards,
Jeff Clune

Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
jclune@...
www.msu.edu/~jclune




> From: Ken <kstanley@...>
> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Date: Thu, 21 Jan 2010 03:17:59 -0000
> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Subject: [neat] Re: CPPN node bloat
> 
> 
> 
> I don't think there's a lot of research that aims to "solve" the problem of
> non-deterministic fitness in part because many people assume it's a good
> thing, and therefore don't recognize that there is a big problem.  However,
> there is research that looks at the issue in more rigorous detail.  For
> example, Shimon Whiteson's paper, "Critical factors in the empirical
> performance of temporal difference and evolutionary methods for reinforcement
> learning," is an excellent study of the effect of nondeterminism and other
> factors on NEAT and SARSA (a value-function-based reinforcement learning
> algorithm):
> 
> http://staff.science.uva.nl/~whiteson/pubs/whitesonjaamas09.pdf
> 
> In particular look at figures 9 and 15.  In figure 9, NEAT rises to a fitness
> of 14 seconds hold time in the traditional nondeterministic Keepaway soccer
> task.  This figure is actually good, and does better than SARSA at 12.
> 
> But in figure 15, in a deterministic version of the task, NEAT rises to an
> amazing 200 seconds of hold time!  SARSA on the other hand only rises to about
> 25 seconds.
> 
> So I think we have to be careful with analyzing the "problem" of
> nondeterminism.  In fact, NEAT is still working relatively well with it, when
> compared to other (non-evolutionary) algorithms.  Yet when the nondeterminism
> is taken away, NEAT is unstoppable, as if it were unleashed.  The story is
> more that determinism is a powerful grease on the wheels of evolution, rather
> than that nondeterminism is cataclysmic.  (It is also important to note that
> the genome that achieves 200 seconds may not be better in general than the one
> that achieves 14 - I don't think Shimon tested both of them in a
> nondeterministic scenario to find out.)
> 
> Personally, I don't think natural evolution handles noise any better.  Great
> people constantly die young, which of course is absolutely deplorable and can
> hardly be "good" for evolution, unless one takes the circular view that
> anything natural evolution does is what it's supposed to do.  (That is, if
> someone died, that must be good because they weren't fit enough.)  I think a
> more reasonable interpretation is that natural evolution succeeded despite
> being handicapped by noise rather than because it handles it in some elusive
> way.  If we could give everyone in nature a fair shake, the whole thing would
> probably go a lot faster and smoother.
> 
> I would guess that this phenomenon is very general.  The more noise, the more
> chaotic evolution becomes.  Of course, there are happy mediums.  Sometimes a
> little noise can help achieve generality at the cost of many evaluations.  Yet
> if it can be avoided somehow by being more clever about being deterministic
> then it should.
> 
> I do view it as a research challenge.  I am not a big fan of noise because of
> its deleterious effects and indeed "deterministic noise" is often better, but
> I believe there may be even better ways to get the generality you want without
> the cost of noise, and I consider it an interesting research question.
> 
> ken
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>> 
>> Thanks for your thoughts on this Ken.
>> 
>> It's a shame that non-deterministic fitness has such an adverse effect here,
>> given that many real problems are noisy, and that natural evolution handles
>> a ton of noise. I wonder if a lot of research has gone into solving this
>> problem. I can't think of anything off the top of my head.
>> 
>> I am curious how general this phenomenon is. Does anyone else out there have
>> non-deterministic fitness functions? Do you see this sort of a bloat in the
>> NEAT networks or HyperNEAT genomes?
>> 
>> 
>> Kind regards,
>> Jeff Clune
>> 
>> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
>> jclune@...
>> www.msu.edu/~jclune
>> 
>> 
>> 
>> 
>>> From: Ken <kstanley@...>
>>> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
>>> Date: Wed, 20 Jan 2010 01:17:26 -0000
>>> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
>>> Subject: [neat] Re: CPPN node bloat
>>> 
>>> 
>>> 
>>> Jeff, first, if fitness is stagnant, then the system should be increasing
>>> the
>>> average number of nodes (though not necessarily the number of nodes in the
>>> champ).  In a stagnant situation, you do not have information (i.e. a
>>> gradient) suggesting which direction is right to go.  Therefore, the most
>>> principled response is to expand your options while never putting all your
>>> eggs in one basket.  When fitness is stagnant, we cannot know if further
>>> search within the currently dimensionality might eventually find a solution,
>>> or if the current dimensionality is insufficient and contains no solution at
>>> all.  In the latter case, the number of nodes and connections would need to
>>> ascend to higher dimensionality.  Because we do not know which case we are
>>> in
>>> when stagnation occurs, the best idea is to try both:  Some species start
>>> arriving with bigger networks while others keep searching in the same old
>>> spaces.  Thus, we would expect the *range* of sizes to increase along with
>>> the
>>> average size.  
>>> 
>>> Your situation with nondeterminism is probably somewhat similar, causing the
>>> average size of solutions to go up because of stagnation.  However, because
>>> the champion will keep changing with the randomized evaluation, you will
>>> observe this phenomenon in the champion itself.  The more noisy it is, the
>>> more it is probably observable (i.e. because the more "random" it is who
>>> happens to look best at any given time, in effect leading to a kind of
>>> sampling of the population through the champion).
>>> 
>>> Of course, that may not be a complete explanation for the steep angle of the
>>> incline.  I would guess that nondeterminism is also causing a general
>>> unhealthiness about the evolutionary process overall. Nondeterminism is
>>> highly
>>> destructive to evolutionary algorithms.  This issue is controversial (even
>>> within my own group!) but my personal opinion is one should avoid
>>> nondeterminism unless it is absolutely essential.  For example, you can
>>> choose
>>> a random order of examples but then subject everyone to the same random set
>>> -
>>> a kind of "deterministic randomness."  Of course, you are banking on the
>>> impartiality of randomness to give you maximal generality, but it will often
>>> be outweighed by its unhealthy side effects on the population.  So I'm
>>> guessing that part of the phenomenon is just a side-effect of an
>>> inconsistent
>>> evaluation scheme leading to relative chaos.
>>> 
>>> There may also be more to it; it merits further investigation as well.
>>> 
>>> ken 
>>> 
>>> 
>>> 
>>> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
>>>> 
>>>> Hello Ken-
>>>> 
>>>> I am plotting the number of CPPN nodes in the generation champion.
>>>> 
>>>> This fitness function is not deterministic (here I am running the bit
>>>> mirroring problem, and I randomly generate 10 different sets of inputs per
>>>> organism per generation). If you look closely at the fitness graph of the
>>>> first image you can see that the fitness line is jumping around a lot
>>>> (though the variation is low).
>>>> 
>>>> In the second plot, interestingly, the two runs that have a constant
>>>> environment (which happens to be deterministic) do not see the huge
>>>> increase
>>>> in CPPN number (it levels out at a healthy level of about 30). The changing
>>>> environments, however, have the runaway CPPN bloat.
>>>> 
>>>> Is there something in NEAT that causes bloat unless you have elitism
>>>> counteracting it? If so, my non-deterministic environments might prevent
>>>> elitism from fighting bloat.
>>>> 
>>>> Have any of you ever turned off elitism and looked at the effect on genome
>>>> size? This may be affecting NEAT as much as HyperNEAT. Alternately, have
>>>> any
>>>> of you looked at genome size in non-deterministic environments?
>>>> 
>>>> Also of interest: I tend to plot the genome node number only for the
>>>> champion, which may be held down due to elitism (when fitness flat lines).
>>>> Have any of you plotted the average number of genome nodes? That number may
>>>> really increase, especially once fitness stagnates...if what I am seeing is
>>>> not pathological.
>>>> 
>>>> Thanks for any thoughts anyone has.
>>>> 
>>>> Kind regards,
>>>> Jeff Clune
>>>> 
>>>> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
>>>> jclune@
>>>> www.msu.edu/~jclune
>>>> 
>>>> 
>>>> 
>>>> 
>>>>> From: Ken <kstanley@>

>>>>> Subject: [neat] Re: CPPN node bloat
>>>>> 
>>>>> 
>>>>> 
>>>>> Jeff, one thing I don't completely understand about your graphs (e.g.
>>>>> graph
>>>>> 1)
>>>>> is that the number of nodes in the champion goes up even when fitness is
>>>>> not
>>>>> going up.  If you have elitism, wouldn't the same champion stick around
>>>>> unchanged?  Perhaps you are seeing that new individuals occasionally come
>>>>> in
>>>>> with the same fitness as the champion, but it would be very surprising if
>>>>> that
>>>>> is happening on every single generation.  Yet that would seem to be the
>>>>> only
>>>>> possibility with the number of champion nodes going up so rapidly even
>>>>> while
>>>>> fitness is flatlined.  So what is going on during the fitness plateau?
>>>>> Which
>>>>> genomes exactly are being measured to get the node counts?
>>>>> 
>>>>> ken
>>>>> 
>>>>> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> Hello all-
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> I have been noticing in many of my HyperNEAT runs recently that the
>>>>>> number
>>>>>> of CPPN nodes is shooting up as a steep linear function of time
>>>>>> (generations), and is relatively unaffected by the fitness trajectory of
>>>>>> the
>>>>>> run. 
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> See here, for example
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> https://www.msu.edu/~jclune/delme/CPPN-Node-Bloat-1.png
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> Sometimes it gets really pathological, with almost 25 CPPN nodes being
>>>>>> added
>>>>>> every 100 generations, such as here:
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> https://www.msu.edu/~jclune/delme/CPPN-Node-Bloat-2.png
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> Oddly, and interestingly, the runs in this second figure where the CPPN
>>>>>> node
>>>>>> count linearly increases are in a changing environment and those runs
>>>>>> where
>>>>>> the CPPN node count flatlines (at a healthy level) are in a constant
>>>>>> environment.
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> Are any of you seeing such bloat?
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> One problem is that it makes the runs slow to a crawl, because running
>>>>>> populations with 200-node genomes is really slow. Moreover, I doubt
>>>>>> evolution can make too much progress with that many nodes (although I
>>>>>> have
>>>>>> seen fitness continue to increase even with such large genomes).
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> I have tried dropping the MutateAddNodeProbability from 0.03 to 0.003 and
>>>>>> that definitely changes the slope of the line, but it still linearly
>>>>>> increases. The good news is that it does not affect fitness to much.
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> Any thoughts?
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> Kind regards,
>>>>>> Jeff Clune
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
>>>>>> jclune@
>>>>>> www.msu.edu/~jclune
>>>>>>
